title: DOS via move_issue

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
### Summary
Moving an issue with a specially-crafted description results in high CPU usage for 60 seconds (request timeout).
Multiple requests can be issued in parallel to create a larger impact.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Given an authorized user (on GitLab.com - anyone can self-register. On EE - depends on instance configuration).
2. Create an issue with the following description (provided a one-line python script to avoid bloating):
3. Once created, move the issue to a different project.

The script:
```python -c "print('![l' * 100000 + '\n')"```
Note: works with a lower number of repetitions too.


### Impact
After 60 seconds (timeout) - the request fails.
Meanwhile, on the server end, (a single) CPU is burnt out (verified against a local EE instance).
Issuing multiple requests in parallel (on multiple GitLab issues) results in multiple CPUs burn out.
Using the DockerHub image, the entire server is completely unavailable by repeatedly sending a small number of requests repeatedly.

### Examples
The bug is instance-independent, works on latest versions. Since GitLab.com is open-core - it would work on GitLab too.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
The HTTP request fails for timeout while the server is burning CPU.

On the code side:
lib/gitlab/gfm/uploads_rewriter.rb / module Gitlab/Gfm / class UploadsRewriter / function files:
```@text.scan(@pattern)```
Where FileUploader::MARKDOWN_PATTERN is assigned to the pattern data member.

MARKDOWN_PATTERN is: 
```\!?\[.*?\]\(/uploads/(?<secret>[0-9a-f]{32})/(?<file>.*?)\)```
The pattern is of a polynomial complexity, thus, the scan results in high CPU utilization.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
Instead of using Ruby’s default Regex engine, use the RE2 engine (or the wrapped version at lib/gitlab/untrusted_regexp.rb), with the following pattern:
```\!?\[.*\]\(/uploads/([0-9a-f]{32})/(.*)\)```
As RE2 does not go beyond O(n), this scan becomes linear.
Note: since RE2 does not support named captures, all references should be fixed - assigning the results to secret/identifier local variables.### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

### Output of checks

#### Results of GitLab environment info

## Impact

A complete denial of service of a GitLab EE instance.
As this vulnerability impacts GitLab.com, we assume that this vulnerability opens the door for a DDOS attack.

activities.message:
p.s.1. This discovery is issued by Gal Ofri & Tor Beer on behalf of Legit Security Ltd.
p.s.2. We want to note that any bounty you find this to be eligible for - Legit Security will donate it.
p.s.3 Just to make clear, this is a REDoS.

Hi @legit-security,

Thank you for your submission. I hope you are well. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Have a great day! 

Kind regards,
@magicmouse

Hello @legit-security - 

Per program policy, this issue is out of scope:

> Rate Limiting (we are aware of the lack of rate-limiting in many places and our application-wide application limits initiative aims to improve that)

As such, I will be closing this as `Informative`


Cheers,

@magicmouse

Hi @magicmouse,
Thank you for your quick response.

In order to improve Gitlab’s security, we would like to ask you some questions to make our research more relevant to GitLab’s security concerns:
1. This vulnerability is a REDoS, which on your pre-submission message box explicitly mentioned as “usually fine” - why doesn’t it apply in this case?
2. Since e.g.https://hackerone.com/reports/1283484 has a very similar impact and flow, we were convinced this vulnerability would be resolved as well. Could you explain what makes the difference?
3. Does Gitlab state that the software is exposed to DoS/REDoS flaws, which cannot be fixed by rate limits? We provide security services for GitLab (and other SCM services). We haven’t found any statements of this kind, and if that is the case, we’d redesign the protection mechanisms needed to deal with GitLab instances.
4. Both reports 1543718 and 1543606 were closed as duplicates of this issue. The reports are different from this one in both exploitation entry points and in the code flow (root cause). Why are these considered duplicates then?

Thank you,
@legit-security

Hi @magicmouse,

Following up on the last comment, there is also the following CVE:
https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-1174
From its description, we can only understand that this vulnerability is very similar (or perhaps identical) to the group of vulnerabilities described in this report and its duplicates.
The vulnerability described in this CVE is claimed to be fixed in 14.9.2, yet we p.o.c'ed the vulnerabilities described in this report on 14.9.3 (the attached code analysis is from 14.9.3's source code as well). Either the patch in 14.9.2 does not properly fix the issue, or this is just a different vulnerability that is similar in its kind.

Could you please elaborate on why this report is being closed, in light of this information?

Disclosure:
We are going to publish a blog post about this topic, which might attract some press releases.
We will, of course, wait for GitLab's response and include any comment you wish to provide (or hold it in case the report is reopened, which implies confidentiality).

Thank you!
@legit-secuirty

Hi @legit-security,

I am reopening this report for investigation, please refrain from publicly disclosing any information related to this report without gitlab's approval, I will pass your report to the gitlab team for review.

Regards,
@princeofpersia

Hello @legit-security,

Thank you for your submission! We were able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Thanks,
@princeofpersia

Hi @kmorrison,
Thank you for your response!
Unfortunately, ‘abc’*100k happens to be a valid attack string. Sorry for not providing a more straight-forward sample.
You can use e.g. 900k repetitions of ‘x’ to demonstrate that the issue is not with the length of the input but the RE expression.
We attached a demo to show that using 900k of ‘x’ works perfectly and the issue moves in seconds,
whilst repetitions of ‘a’ (another attack string) cause the issue to fail to move and cause high CPU utilization.
Please let us know if there’s anything else we can do to make things clearer.
Thanks,
@legit-security

@legit-security thanks for the video. For sure there is a problem here. My next question is, how can this be leveraged into an actual attack? Moving one bad issue causes a timeout, but doesn't take down my instance. I'm thinking that setting up multiple issues and moving them simultaneously might push the Attack Complexity to "high" and lower the CVSS score.

Hi @kmorrison,
Indeed, moving a single issue occupies a single CPU.
Each move will use 100% cpu for 1 minute - the complete denial of service is derived from the amount of cpus on your gitlab instance - in the default Docker instance, 5 moves of malicious issues cause a complete denial of service.
Note that the attack can be automated by issuing API commands or a scripted browser instance, and that the same set of issues can be used repeatedly, so we believe it doesn’t increase the complexity.
Thanks,
@legit-security

ETA for fix:

Hi @legit-security,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2022-07-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team
As mentioned in https://hackerone.com/reports/1544465#activity-16784881 this has an unauthenticated exploitation path via the markdown API.

[CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H](https://gitlab-com.gitlab.io/gl-security/appsec/cvss-calculator/#vector=CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H&range=new) (7.5 High / $7,640.00 / new bounty range)

Hi @legit-security,

High severity awards are eligible for a partial award at time of triage, which is $1000. Congratulations! I note you wanted to donate this to charity, so refer to https://docs.hackerone.com/hackers/payments.html#donating-bounties-to-charity if you haven't seen that already.

Cheers,
Nick Malcolm
GitLab Security Team

ETA for fix:

Hi @legit-security,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2022-06-30.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @nmalcolm_gitlab
Thank you for your response! We appreciate your time and effort spent reviewing these issues!

We think there's a slight misunderstanding that is still outstanding.
As per our understanding, there are two root causes in play here. They are very similar on the surface, yet they have different origins.
Aside from the deeper analysis, the "a"*900k attack string is a clear indication here: it can be used in one case but not the other.
To avoid any confusion, we summarized the whole thing in the following table:

|                |Markup REDoS                   |Markup Engine DOS            |
|----------------|-------------------------------|-----------------------------|
|Attack Vectors|Move Issue|API Markdown Endpoint, Preview/Create/Update Issue|
|Relevant Issues|  #1543584          |#1544465, #1543718, #1543606|
|Root Cause|Regex Check            |Banzai Markup Engine            |
|Code Ref       |`lib/gitlab/gfm/uploads_rewriter.rb`|`banzai/reference_extractor.rb`|
|Attack with 'a'*900k|Attack succeeds|Attack fails|
|Attack with '![l'*300k|Attack succeeds|Attack succeeds|
|Privilege Required|Authenticated|Unauthenticated, authenticated (respectively)|

You can read further info on each root cause in the different reports.
Please let us know if you need further info, as we don't want the patch to miss either spot.
In addition, please let us know if that changes the status for #1543584.

Thanks,
@legit-security

Hi @legit-security,

At this stage the engineering team responsible for the code have said it's the same root cause. However [I have passed on your message](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/362379#note_955779025) seeking explicit confirmation and will let you know. (The issue is still confidential until 90 days after patch).

Cheers,
Nick Malcolm
GitLab Security Team

Hi again @legit-security,

The engineering team confirmed your comment! Since we imported https://hackerone.com/reports/1543718 already I'll treat that as the main issue, and set its severity based on the unauthenticated path.

Cheers,
Nick Malcolm
GitLab Security Team
This specific attack cannot be performed unauthenticated. See also: https://hackerone.com/reports/1543718

ETA for fix:

Hi @legit-security,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2022-07-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

ETA for fix:

Hi @legit-security,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2022-08-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @legit-security,
Sorry for the long delay in getting back to you on this report. Our engineering team found that this vulnerability was already fixed as part of an unrelated performance improvement effort, via this merge request: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/86708

I have tested it and can no longer reproduce the DOS via moving an issue with the payload in your report. If you'd like to confirm that yourself, and find that it is not fixed, please let us know. In the meantime I'm paying out the remaining balance of the bounty.

Regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @kmorrison,

Thank you for the update!
First, we'd like to proceed to CVE publication.
Can you please share the process of publishing the vulnerability as a CVE and the expected time frame?

We’d also like to inform you that the code is still vulnerable, although the attack changed a bit.
We’re not sure if the following issue should be reported separately, so let us know if you’d like us to open a new report for that.

First, the “move” attack vector:
Indeed, moving an issue does not trigger the original ReDOS anymore.
Nonetheless, it does trigger the Banzai-related DOS (#1543718).
As previously mentioned, this vulnerability can be exploited only using the repeated `[!l` payload, not the repeated `a` payload. This is probably why it didn’t reproduce in your tests.

Now, the new attack vector created with the fix is the `/clone` attack vector:
Since the patch moves the usage of the markdown pattern to the notes’ cloning code, it becomes the new trigger.
So, the new attack flow is:
* Create an issue with the repeated `[!l` payload.
* Comment e.g.: `/clone --with_notes same_user/same_org`

You should note that the patch changes the MARKDOWN_PATTERN usage from `scan` to `match`.
We're not sure if that change was intentional, but anyway, it did impact the attack string: the repeated `a` payload cannot be used to exploit it anymore, and only the repeated `[!l` payload can be used now.

We'd be glad to hear your reply to our open questions, and please let us know if there's any further explanation needed regarding this new attack vector (and root cause).
Thank you,
@legit-security

Clarification:
There was a typo in the last comment.
The payload is repeated `![l`, not `[!l]`, i.e.
`python3 -c 'print("![l" * 300000)'`

Hi @legit-security,
Thank you and yes, we are aware that the other issue as identified in #1543718 is still an issue, and that report is still open. I will make a note in that issue on GitLab that this /clone attack vector with "move" will also trigger that DOS. As you know, the issue in #1543718 was traced back to commonmarker. Is this new attack vector the same as that?  If so, I think we are ok to leave this issue resolved and continue with #1543718. If not, I will reopen this one.

Regards,
@kmorrison
GitLab Security Team

Hi @kmorrison,

As far as we understand things, the handling should be:
1. For the commonmarker case: add the "move_issue" attack vector to #1543718.
2. For the MARKDOWN_PATTERN case, either:
*  Reopen this report to handle the `/clone` attack vector.
* Keep this report closed and open a new report for the `/clone` attack vector, since the root cause changed (it is still the MARKDOWN_PATTERN, but [https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/86708](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/86708) introduced a new root cause).

Since the pattern is DOS-prone, we strongly recommend fixing it by changing it to an RE2 pattern instead - as described in the original description of this report.
Thanks,
@legit-security

ETA for fix:

Hi @legit-security,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2022-09-30.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @legit-security,

Thank you again for the report! Your finding has been patched in GitLab version 15.4.1. Congratulations!

The CVE assigned to this vulnerability is CVE-2022-3283

Please let us know if you find that our patch does not mitigate your finding. Your report will be published in 30 days in GitLab's issue tracker. If you'd like to publicly disclose this report or details of it in a blog post or elsewhere, please allow 30 days to pass before doing so to give time to our customers to upgrade to a patched version.

We look forward to your next report!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

summaries.content:
We are Legit Security, a company building a solution that protects development environments and pipelines from security risks such as software supply-chain attacks and sensitive data exposure.
You can read a bit about us at http://www.legitsecurity.com.
